content: Inland waterways, including the Inland Waterway System managed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, cover 25,000 miles and handle half of all inland waterway freight. The Corps maintains navigation channels, harbors, locks, and dams on these waterways. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers manages the Inland Waterway System, covering 25,000 miles and handling half of all national freight. The Corps funds maintenance and construction through appropriations and user fees, with costs shared for new construction or major rehabilitation. The current funding model for the Inland Waterway System is facing challenges as the existing revenue source is insufficient to cover nonfederal costs of major capital expenditures, leading to federal taxpayers covering more than half of these costs. This shortfall is limiting new and ongoing construction projects on inland waterways.
